1



construction of the Russell Street viaduct and its connection to the
Washington-Baltimore Expressway.

Transportation Study Plan

A comprehensive analysis of existing traffic conditions in the Balti-
more metropolitan area was initiated in 1945 by the State Roads Com-
mission in cooperation with the City of Baltimore and the U. S. Public
Roads Administration. This study, officially identified as the Transpor-
tation Study—Baltimore Metropolitan Area, included the most extensive
origin and destination analysis thus far undertaken in the Baltimore area.
William F. Childs, Jr., then Director of the Traffic Division, State Roads
Commission, served as Director of the Study, and the report issued in
October, 1946, is sometimes referred to as the Childs Report.

The Transportation Study Report presented three possible routes for
a cross-town freeway and then analyzed each of these routes from the
standpoint of their ability to serve traffic needs. All three routes coincide
from the southwest City boundary to St. Paul Street and for this stretch
roughly approximate the main cross-town route included in the Smith
Plan. From St. Paul Street to the eastern City boundary the northerly
route also approximates the Smith Plan; the middle route approximates
Route A as previously described; and the southern route, referred to in
the Transportation Study Report as Route C, is a wholly new alignment
running between Bank and Gough Streets. All three routes are shown
on Sheet 4.

The report concludes that “Route C on the basis of the data obtained
and presented serves the needs of the study area as expressed by the
desires of the motorists better than [the other two routes].” Despite this
conclusion it appears that no further consideration was ever given to
Route C.

1949 Plan

In 1949 the Planning Commission published A Tentative Master
Transportation Plan, outlining proposals for a complete system of express-
ways within the City including a cross-town expressway. (See Sheet 5).
The western and central legs of the cross-town expressway are identical
to the Smith proposals. The east leg crosses the Fallsway at the same
point as Route A but then follows a wholly new route approximating
Eager Street. This leg joins the Pulaski Highway at about Erdman Ave-
nue. It will be seen that this eastern leg lies midway between Route A
and Route B.

The 1949 Plan is based upon an inner ring similar to that proposed
by Smith. The eastern side of this inner ring is again an elevated struc-
ture over the Fallsway, but instead of continuing north along Barclay
Street to serve the northeast it swings around to the northwest and runs
up the Jones Falls Valley. This route has, of course, become the Jones
Falls Expressway.

While the 1949 Plan assumes that the main cross-town traffic flow
would come in from the southwest via the Russell Street route, it adds a
depressed expressway running from the inner ring due west between Mul-
berry and Franklin Streets to the Pennsylvania Railroad at which point
it merges with Edmondson Avenue. This proposal is referred to in the
Plan as the West Radial. It will be seen that it is identical to a portion
of the main cross-town route proposed by the Advisory Engineers and also
included as part of Route A and of the Moses Plan.

1957 Plan

After 1949 a number of developments occurred affecting expressway
plans, and corresponding revisions were worked out by the Planning Com-
mission and embodied at various times in the Master Plan. The last such
change was made on December 18, 1957, and the expressway pattern as
